name: It's Lit: Cosy Pubs with Open Fires

text.text: It's Lit: Cosy Pubs with Open Fires

With the weather well and truly against us, it's time to accept reality: freezing is the new norm and the sooner we accept it the better. Winter has come. Deal with it.  

It's not all bad though. With winter comes warm alcoholic beverages, skipping work because of "flu", and huddling round an open fire. If your landlord's not on board with your attempts to un-brick that "decorative chimney", there are still plenty of places you can get in on the fun. Here are some of the best.

tip.text: While Tufnell Park is by no means short of banging pubs, The Pineapple might just take the biscuit. Tucked away from the buzz of the main road yet fantastically rowdy in its own right – the spectacular crew behind this North London boozer know exactly what’s up. This beautiful listed building is home to guaranteed romping good times, with ‘Cheese Thursdays’ (donate £3 to a colossal pub cheeseboard and dig in knowing your change is going to the homeless), a stellar Thai kitchen upstairs and £5 lunches. Oh, and there’s two pub cats with a penchant for prawns and scuttling around the place. Meow.

text.text: A charming little public house in Tufnell Park, The Pineapple's business is all about cosy. Pokey corridors leading to nooks filled with plush sofas and open fires. Our only issue is that you can find yourself overheating when you're this close to the heat - but you can always head out to the conservatory to cool off.

tip.text:
The Chesham Arms is really all you could want from a pub - an open fire, a well curated selection of bevs, a nice little balcony, and a huge garden out back with wooden benches for the squares and hay bales for the more whimsical punters.

The garden is a real afternoon sun trap, making the call of afterwork pints very hard to resist if you’re lucky/unlucky enough to have The Chesham lying in wait on your commute home. But, guilt aside, once you’ve plonked yourself on a hay bale, with one hand around a cold pint and the other patting some stranger's dog, you’ll start to think that going to the pub everyday isn’t so bad after all. And with Yard Sale Pizza a phone call away, there isn't actually a reason to ever leave. Ever.

text.text: The Chesham Arms is a real community cornerstone. With its big back garden it's a winner in summer, but it also holds its own through the dark days that bookend the year. Huddle up by the open fire with a creamy milk stout and a Yard Sale pizza and slip into a deep hibernation state.

tip.text:
We'll admit it...we first went into Lord Morpeth because we heard they had a working Pac Man machine as a table. Took us about a minute to see the 'Sourdough Saloon' menu on the table, so we got right on that like the greedy chancers we are. The pizzas they whip up are here are excellent: crisp bases, Rovagnati ham, fresh chilli, the best mozzarella...everything you need.

They throw in some good craft beers and a small cocktail list into the mix too. There's a pub quiz on Thursdays, live music some Fridays, and an open fire. Oh, and a jukebox and Star Wars pinball machine (we were obviously going to include those).

text.text: There's a lot that goes hand in hand with an open fire - marshmallows, hot chocolate, and... a Pac Man machine? It may not be a well-known combo, but Lord Morpeth might be onto something here. Snuggle up by the fire, play a game or two, and have a lovely, snug afternoon.

tip.text:
The Antelope is the best pub in Tooting. Maybe even the entire world (don't @ us). It's a gargantuan space - all wood panelling, stained glass, and high ceilings, lending it the distinct vibe of an old village hall. Except it's been a pub since the 1800s, and retains plenty of that old-world charm, including a hefty dose of taxidermy and old leather wingbacks perfect for an extended cotch. Head out back - through the opulent dining room - and you'll find a huuuge beer garden perfect for sunny day sippin'. Did we mention the open fireplace? No? Well there's that, too.

Also, they've got one of the best Sunday roasts around, and a pretty solid pub grub menu for the rest of the week. In the evenings, there's good clean quiz fun on a Monday, live music Thursday and Sunday, plus DJs at the weekends.

text.text: This British boozer is a great spot to escape the harsh winter winds, with its good ale selection, taxidermy displays, old leather wingbacks, and open fireplace.

tip.text:
This teeny pub just off Brick Lane is something of a miracle: in the heart of gentrified East London, surrounded by forward-thinking, trend-setting creatives, it has somehow managed to stay exactly as all the pubs used to be circa 1965-2005. Dusty regulars; the warming smell of hops and spilt beer; and carpets (remember when all the pubs had carpets?) make you feel like you’ve stepped to a time where choices were simple. Ale or larger? Nuts or crisps? Zero eye contact or a broken jaw?

It's a special place: there’s a cat, the ale is great, and one time we were there they brought out paper plates piled with cocktail sausages and roast potatoes and left them around for people to eat, just because. It’s been here for about two hundred years, here’s to two hundred more.

text.text: The Pride is a pub from back when pubs were pubs. A real pub's pub. A pub amongst pubs. It's a pub. Carpeted floors, ale-tinged velvets seats, and a free-roaming cat all work with the open fire to make you feel right at home. If your home is a pub, that is.

tip.text:
What was once a boozer with a dodgy rep on the Murder Mile has gradually earned its place in people's hearts as a loveable, slightly scruffy community hub with hella soul. There’s been no million-pound facelift here (or however much pub facelifts cost), instead, you’ll find a creaking tavern with plenty of nooks and crannies adorned in random vintage bits and bobs, worn floorboards, log fires and mismatched furniture.

This is a big pub with the intimacy and charm of a small one: where weekly comedy nights are legendary and a late Saturday night pitstop will be rewarded with an unpretentious raucous dance to Wham or suchlike. Add in one of the biggest beer gardens in East and you’ve got yourself all you require from a neighbourhood boozer.

text.text: A lovely little boozer located on Hackney’s iconic Murder Mile. Having previously been one of those pubs you avoid at all costs, The Clapton Hart has gone and done a bloody good job at brushing off its shoddy reputation. Now it's a welcoming pub, with warm fireplaces to nestle close to and have a good chin-wag with a mate.

tip.text: Housed within what was once a grand hotel, The Salisbury has got to be the best pub on Green Lanes. It's huge with ornate ceilings and ageing taxidermy and the beer selection is more than generous. Snuggle down in a private booth and have a go on the jukebox.

text.text: This grand old crooner may seem too large to be cosy, but give it a chance and you'll soon find plenty of intimate corners to hunker down in. Our favourite is the leather armchair by the fire. We reckon you'll like it too.

tip.text:
If you have a soft spot for that Victorian-esque genre of pub, you are really going to dig the historic Jerusalem Tavern. With the worn wooden floorboards, heavy oak furniture, deft tiles, peeling paint and taxidermy (okay, that's an anomaly), it seems to hark way back to a simpler time. And it does: the 1990s. But it is a faithful replication and, to be fair to them, the concept of the Jerusalem Tavern has existed around this area in some shape or other since 1720.

Inside it's full of small, cosy snugs and nooks which really fill up after work - don't be surprised to find yourself in the alley outside with a jar in hand. If you manage to get a table by the open fire, we suggest you go and buy a lottery ticket immediately. Beer comes courtesy of St Peter's Brewery in Suffolk and is extremely delicious, if you're into your ales. It's a real atmospheric public house to have a pint in - a trip back to ye olde London of 1996.

text.text: Wonky and wonderful is The Jerusalem Tavern. You'll find drunkards and business people alike, all basking in the warmth from the open fire. Swing by on the weekend and tuck into a big ol' roast while you wash down those real ales.

tip.text:
Every aspect of this pub feels like a direct push-back against the corporate, chain, soulless, Fosters-serving, beer-and-burger-deal-having, laminated-menu megapub fuckery that has no doubt taken over your old local. These guys are serving strictly real ales and ciders from independent suppliers (they do wine and spirit-mixers but they look at you funny when you order them); they only take cash; and for food they have a small range of tasty pies, scotch eggs, and pork belly sandwiches served with a crusty-as-all-hell roll and punchy piccalilli.

Now, before you start scoffing and muttering ‘hipster’ you should know that this is maybe the least pretentious pub we've been to. It’s mostly just old ale enthusiasts chilling the fuck out on repurposed church furniture - or in the teeny back garden - and basking in their love of all things curmudgeonly.

text.text: This relaxed, homely venue has a mission to only stock beers and ciders from small, independent UK breweries. The decor is real nice too, no swirly carpets that make you feel drunker than you are, just repurposed church benches, some lovely tileage, and an open fireplace that emanates plenty of heat.
